author: Shefali Anand
title: Adviser Goes for the Alternative
text:
1 COMMENTS Volatility in the markets has helped reinforce the benefits of owning alternative funds that behave differently than stocks, says Rick Kahler, an investment adviser in Rapid City, S.D.
Earlier in the year, some of Mr. Kahler’s clients asked him why they had allocations to funds that invest in derivatives and other securities that weren’t moving in lockstep with the rising stock market.

Our College Q&A U.S.-Stock Funds Fall 8.2% in Quarter The questions ended when stocks declined this summer. “Now, they’re saying, ‘I’m not down as much as I expected,’ ” says Mr. Kahler, president of Kahler Financial Group.
For clients who can handle moderate risk, Mr. Kahler allocates 20% of the portfolio to three funds he describes as “absolute return” funds. He expects them to produce returns similar to or slightly lower than stocks, but with less volatility. These funds can be pricey, but “we feel that it’s worth the extra cost,” says Nikolas Boyce, investment analyst associate at the firm.
In this column, we feature model portfolios from investment advisers who mainly use mutual funds and exchange-traded funds. Kahler Financial manages around $200 million, mainly for wealthy individuals.
Here, Kahler advisers share a model portfolio for investors who can handle moderate risk. The portfolio as structured would have gained 7% annually over the five years ended Aug. 31, the advisers say. This would be before the adviser’s fee of 1% for the first $1 million and lower for more assets.
